expanded_description: Uniform motion is the simplest type of motion—movement at constant velocity in a straight line. Understanding uniform motion provides the foundation for analyzing more complex motions and serves as a reference case for comparison.

core_concept.principle: Uniform motion occurs when an object moves at constant velocity—constant speed in a straight line without changing direction. In uniform motion, velocity is constant, acceleration is zero, and equal displacements occur in equal time intervals.
core_concept.explanation: Uniform motion is motion without acceleration. The object covers equal distances in equal times, maintaining the same speed and direction throughout. Position changes at a constant rate. Mathematically, for uniform motion: $v = \text{constant}$, $a = 0$, and $x = x_i + v\Delta t$. This type of motion is idealized—perfect uniform motion rarely occurs in real life due to friction, air resistance, and other forces—but it's an excellent approximation for many situations (car on cruise control, train on straight track, object sliding on ice). Understanding uniform motion is essential because it's the simplest case and provides a baseline for understanding accelerated motion.

sections.introduction: Uniform motion has distinct characteristics that make it easy to identify and analyze.

key_concept.definition: Uniform motion is characterized by: (1) constant velocity (both magnitude and direction), (2) zero acceleration, (3) straight-line path, (4) equal displacements in equal time intervals, (5) position changing at constant rate.
key_concept.context: These characteristics are all equivalent—if any one is true, the others follow. Recognizing uniform motion allows us to use simpler equations without acceleration terms.

principles.statement: In uniform motion, velocity does not change. Speed and direction remain constant throughout.
principles.application: If velocity is constant, you can use $v = \text{constant}$ throughout the motion.
principles.example: Car on cruise control at 25 m/s: velocity stays at +25 m/s constantly. Not speeding up, not slowing down, not turning.

principles.statement: Since velocity doesn't change, acceleration must be zero: $a = 0$.
principles.application: If $a = 0$, motion is uniform. If $a \neq 0$, motion is not uniform.
principles.example: No acceleration means no forces (or balanced forces). Object on ice continues at constant velocity because friction is negligible.

principles.statement: Uniform motion occurs in a straight line. Any curved path involves changing direction, which means changing velocity (acceleration).
principles.application: Object must move in one direction without turning.
principles.example: Train on straight track at constant speed: uniform motion ✓. Car going around curve at constant speed: NOT uniform motion (direction changing, so velocity changing).

principles.statement: The object covers the same displacement in every equal time interval.
principles.application: Predictable, repeating pattern in position changes.
principles.example: Every second, position increases by 10 m: $t = 0$: $x = 0$ m, $t = 1$ s: $x = 10$ m, $t = 2$ s: $x = 20$ m, $t = 3$ s: $x = 30$ m. Always +10 m each second.

principles.statement: Position changes linearly with time: $x = x_i + v\Delta t$ or $x = x_i + vt$ (if starting at $t = 0$).
principles.application: Graph of position vs time is a straight line with slope = velocity.
principles.example: Start at $x_i = 5$ m, velocity $v = 3$ m/s: $x = 5 + 3t$. At $t = 4$ s: $x = 5 + 3(4) = 17$ m.

characteristics: No mention of acceleration or forces
Equal time intervals with equal distance covered
classifications.behavior: Look for indicators of constant velocity.

examples.explanation: Explicitly states uniform motion. $v = \text{constant}$, $a = 0$.
Constant speed + straight line = constant velocity = uniform motion.
Implies constant velocity, uniform motion.
Equal distances in equal times = uniform motion.

classifications.behavior: Any change in velocity → not uniform.

examples.explanation: Velocity increasing → not constant → not uniform.
Slowing down due to gravity → velocity decreasing → not uniform.
Direction changing → velocity changing → not uniform (even if speed constant).
Speed and direction constantly changing → not uniform.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Uniform Motion
worked_examples.problem: Which of the following represent uniform motion? (a) Car travels at 60 km/h on straight highway for 30 minutes. (b) Runner completes 400 m track in 60 s. (c) Ball rolls down ramp. (d) Train travels 150 km in 2 hours on straight track.

step_by_step.explanation: Constant speed (60 km/h) + straight line + constant time = constant velocity. This IS uniform motion ✓
Track is circular (400 m track implies oval). Direction constantly changing → velocity changing → NOT uniform motion ✗
Ball rolling down ramp: gravity accelerates it → speeding up → velocity increasing → NOT uniform motion ✗

We can calculate average speed (150 km / 2 h = 75 km/h), but problem doesn't say speed is constant. Train could have sped up, slowed down, stopped. Cannot confirm uniform motion without more information.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) IS uniform motion. (b) and (c) are NOT uniform. (d) Cannot determine without more information.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Uniform motion requires constant velocity (constant speed + straight line). Changing direction or changing speed → not uniform.

image.alt: Checklist showing characteristics of uniform motion
image.caption: Uniform motion: ✓ constant velocity, ✓ zero acceleration, ✓ straight line, ✓ equal distances in equal times

sections.introduction: For uniform motion, position can be calculated using a simple linear relationship with time.

key_concept.definition: For uniform motion, position at any time is given by: $x = x_i + v\Delta t$ or equivalently $x = x_i + vt$ (if $t_i = 0$). This equation says: position equals initial position plus displacement (velocity times time).
key_concept.context: This is the fundamental equation for uniform motion. It's simpler than equations for accelerated motion because there's no $a$ term. Knowing initial position and constant velocity, you can predict position at any future time.

principles.statement: Position increases (or decreases) linearly with time. The relationship is a straight line.
principles.application: Graph of $x$ vs $t$ is straight line with slope = $v$, intercept = $x_i$.

principles.statement: For uniform motion: $\Delta x = v\Delta t$. Displacement is simply velocity multiplied by time interval.
principles.application: Knowing velocity and time, instantly calculate displacement.
principles.example: Travel at $v = 20$ m/s for $\Delta t = 5$ s: $\Delta x = 20 \times 5 = 100$ m.

principles.statement: The position equation can be written multiple ways, all equivalent.
principles.application: Choose form that's clearest for the problem.
principles.example: $x = x_i + vt$ (if start timing at $t = 0$). $x = x_i + v(t - t_i)$ (if start timing at $t = t_i$). $x = x_i + v\Delta t$ (using time interval explicitly).

worked_examples.title: Finding Position at Later Time
worked_examples.problem: A car starts at position $x_i = 20$ m and travels at constant velocity $v = +15$ m/s. Where is the car at time $t = 8$ s?

step_by_step.explanation: Started at 20 m, moved in positive direction at 15 m/s for 8 s → should be far in positive direction. 140 m makes sense ✓

worked_examples.concept_applied: Use $x = x_i + vt$ to find position at any time during uniform motion.

worked_examples.title: Finding Time to Reach Position
worked_examples.problem: An object at $x_i = 5$ m travels at $v = +8$ m/s. When does it reach position $x = 45$ m?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rearrange to $t = (x - x_i)/v$ when finding time to reach a position.

worked_examples.title: Negative Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A car at $x_i = 100$ m travels at constant velocity $v = -12$ m/s. (a) Where is it at $t = 4$ s? (b) When does it reach $x = 0$ m?

step_by_step.explanation: Negative velocity means moving in negative direction. Started at 100 m, moved toward origin, now at 52 m.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $x = 52$ m at $t = 4$ s, (b) Reaches origin at $t = 8.33$ s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Negative velocity means position decreases over time. Equation works the same way—just use negative value for $v$.

worked_examples.title: Meeting Point of Two Objects
worked_examples.problem: Object A starts at $x_A = 0$ m with velocity $v_A = +10$ m/s. Object B starts at $x_B = 80$ m with velocity $v_B = -5$ m/s. When and where do they meet?
worked_examples.final_answer: They meet at $t = 5.33$ s, at position $x = 53.3$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: For two objects in uniform motion, set their position equations equal to find when/where they meet.

worked_examples.title: Distance Traveled vs Final Position
worked_examples.problem: An object starts at $x_i = 30$ m and travels at $v = -6$ m/s for 5 seconds. Find (a) final position, (b) displacement, (c) distance traveled.

step_by_step.calculation: $\Delta x = -30$ m (moved 30 m in negative direction)

step_by_step.explanation: Uniform motion in one direction: distance = |displacement| = |-30| = 30 m
For uniform motion without direction reversal, distance = |displacement|. Both are 30 m here.

worked_examples.concept_applied: For straight-line uniform motion, distance traveled equals magnitude of displacement.

image.alt: Diagram showing position changing linearly with time
image.caption: Uniform motion: $x = x_i + vt$. Position changes linearly with time.

sections.introduction: Graphs provide powerful visual representation of uniform motion, making patterns and relationships clear.

key_concept.definition: For uniform motion: (1) Position-time graph is a straight line with slope = velocity. (2) Velocity-time graph is a horizontal line at the constant velocity value. (3) Acceleration-time graph is a horizontal line at zero.
key_concept.context: Graphs allow you to see motion characteristics at a glance. Slope and shape of graphs encode information about velocity and acceleration.

classifications.behavior: Visual representation of position changing at constant rate.

examples.explanation: Upward-sloping line (slope > 0). Position increasing with time. Moving in positive direction.
Downward-sloping line (slope < 0). Position decreasing with time. Moving in negative direction.
Horizontal line (slope = 0). Position not changing. Object stationary.
Slope = $\frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = v$. Measure slope to find velocity.
Positive constant velocity. Moving in positive direction at steady speed.
Negative constant velocity. Moving in negative direction at steady speed.
Zero velocity. Object at rest.
Area under $v$-$t$ graph = $v \times \Delta t = \Delta x$. Rectangle area gives displacement.

classifications.behavior: Shows acceleration is zero throughout uniform motion.

examples.explanation: Acceleration is zero at all times during uniform motion. Velocity not changing.

worked_examples.title: Reading Position-Time Graph
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph shows a straight line passing through points $(t = 0$ s, $x = 10$ m) and $(t = 5$ s, $x = 35$ m). Find (a) velocity, (b) position equation, (c) position at $t = 8$ s.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Slope of position-time graph equals velocity. Use slope and intercept to write position equation.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting Velocity-Time Graph
worked_examples.problem: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $v = -8$ m/s from $t = 0$ to $t = 6$ s. Find (a) acceleration, (b) displacement during this time.

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal line on $v$-$t$ graph means velocity constant. Slope of $v$-$t$ graph = acceleration.
Displacement = area under $v$-$t$ graph. Rectangle: width = 6 s, height = -8 m/s
Displacement = -48 m means moved 48 m in negative direction.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Horizontal $v$-$t$ line indicates uniform motion ($a = 0$). Area under line gives displacement.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Two Objects on Position-Time Graph
worked_examples.problem: On the same position-time graph: Object A's line has slope +10 m/s starting at $x_i = 0$. Object B's line has slope +4 m/s starting at $x_i = 30$ m. (a) Which is faster? (b) When do they have the same position?

step_by_step.calculation: Object A is faster (10 m/s > 4 m/s)

step_by_step.explanation: Write equations: A: $x_A = 0 + 10t = 10t$. B: $x_B = 30 + 4t$. Set equal: $10t = 30 + 4t$
B starts ahead (at 30 m) but A is faster. A catches up to B at $t = 5$ s. After that, A pulls ahead.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Object A is faster (10 m/s vs 4 m/s), (b) Same position at $t = 5$ s
worked_examples.concept_applied: On position-time graph, steeper slope = faster speed. Lines crossing = objects at same position.

image.caption: Uniform motion graphs: $x$-$t$ is straight line (slope = $v$), $v$-$t$ is horizontal (constant), $a$-$t$ is zero

sections.introduction: Comparing uniform motion to accelerated motion clarifies what makes uniform motion special and when it applies.

key_concept.definition: Uniform motion is the special case where $a = 0$ and $v = \text{constant}$. Accelerated motion has $a \neq 0$ and $v$ changes. Different equations and graph shapes apply to each.
key_concept.context: Recognizing whether motion is uniform or accelerated determines which equations to use and what to expect.

examples.explanation: Straight line
Horizontal line
Cruise control, ice skating at constant speed, train on straight track at steady pace
Curved line (parabola for constant $a$)
Sloped line (for constant $a$)
Car accelerating, ball falling, rocket launching

image.alt: Side-by-side comparison of graphs for uniform vs accelerated motion
image.caption: Uniform motion: straight $x$-$t$, flat $v$-$t$. Accelerated motion: curved $x$-$t$, sloped $v$-$t$

sections.introduction: While perfect uniform motion is rare in reality, many situations approximate it well enough to use uniform motion analysis.

categories.description: Situations where uniform motion model works well.

examples.explanation: Electronic system maintains constant speed. On flat, straight road: excellent uniform motion approximation.
Between stations, train often travels at constant velocity. Uniform motion applies for most of journey.
Once at altitude, airplane maintains constant velocity for long periods. Good uniform motion example.
Very low friction means negligible deceleration. Motion is nearly uniform until object slows significantly or hits edge.
In vacuum, no air resistance. Speed constant in orbit (though direction changes—only speed constant for circular orbit).
Velocity changing rapidly. Must use accelerated motion equations.
Gravity causes constant acceleration. Not uniform motion.
Slowing down due to gravity. Negative acceleration—not uniform.
Even at constant speed, direction changing means velocity changing. Curved path is never uniform motion.
Estimate travel time assuming constant average speed: time = distance / speed.
Two objects traveling at constant velocities—when/where do they meet?
At constant highway speed, calculate safe following distance based on reaction time.

summary: Uniform motion is motion at constant velocity—constant speed in a straight line with zero acceleration. Characteristics: (1) velocity is constant ($v = \text{constant}$), (2) acceleration is zero ($a = 0$), (3) motion is in straight line (no turns), (4) equal displacements occur in equal time intervals, (5) position changes at constant rate. The fundamental equation is $x = x_i + vt$ (or $x = x_i + v\Delta t$), which gives position as a linear function of time. For uniform motion: displacement equals velocity times time ($\Delta x = v\Delta t$), and distance traveled equals magnitude of displacement (for motion without direction reversal). Graphically: position-time graph is straight line with slope = velocity; velocity-time graph is horizontal line at constant velocity value (slope = 0 indicating no acceleration); acceleration-time graph is horizontal line at zero. The slope of the $x$-$t$ graph directly gives velocity; area under the $v$-$t$ graph gives displacement. Uniform motion is the simplest case of motion and serves as important reference for understanding more complex accelerated motion. It's a good approximation for: cruise control on highway, train between stations, airplane at cruising altitude, object on ice. Not applicable when: speeding up, slowing down, turning (curved path), any acceleration present. Understanding uniform motion is essential because it's the foundation for analyzing all motion—accelerated motion is understood as departure from uniform motion. Many everyday situations approximate uniform motion well enough to use its simple equations for practical calculations.
